block.p: Diageo Said to Be in Talks For All or Part of Bestfoods Diageo, which owns Pillsbury bakery goods and Haagen-Daz ice cream, is negotiating to buy all or part of Bestfoods, the maker of Skippy peanut butter and Hellmann's mayonnaise, executives close to the talks said.

Diageo is holding trans-Atlantic negotiations with Bestfoods in hopes of combining Bestfoods' bakery business with its own bakery business and possibly spinning off the newly combined unit into a company that might be controlled by Bestfoods' management, the executives said. [Page C2.]

2 Big Deals in Business-to-Business The consolidation of the business-to-business software market accelerated with two big deals. Vignette said it was acquiring OnDisplay in a $1.7 billion stock swap, while WebMethods is buying Active Software in a stock deal valued at $1.3 billion. Shares of Vignette fell $8.9375, to $34.875, while OnDisplay rose 87.5 cents, to $54.125. WebMethods fell $15, to $72, while Active Software dropped 93.75 cents, to $32.0625, all on Nasdaq. [C6.]

Battle Over Trade Bill Beginning With just two days to go before Congress decides whether to upgrade economic ties with China, corporate supporters opened a $1 million advertising blitz and labor opponents stormed Capitol Hill as both camps struggled to recruit a handful of undecided lawmakers who hold the key to victory or defeat. [A1.]

Microsoft Files Unexpected Brief Microsoft filed an unexpected brief with a federal judge that quoted from a five-year-old government legal document in which the Justice Department argued that breaking up Microsoft would be ''against the public interest.'' The document risks annoying the judge, who did not ask for another filing from Microsoft when he laid out the schedule for the remedy phase of the antitrust case. [C6.]

New Effort for Global Accounting The goal of establishing worldwide accounting standards -- making it possible for companies to compile one set of books for investors everywhere -- may be moving closer to reality with new efforts to put together an international standards setter. [C2.]

Napster Receives New Financing Napster, the Internet music site that has incurred the wrath of the recording industry, received $15 million in new financing from Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, which also placed one of its partners, Hank Barry, as the company's interim chief executive. [C27.]

Gruner & Jahr Appoints New Chief Gruner & Jahr, the publisher of seven consumer magazines in the United States including McCall's, Fitness and Parents, has named Daniel B. Brewster chief executive, three months after its previous chief departed. Mr. Brewster, who has resigned as president and chief executive of American Express Publishing, will start his new position on June 5. [C6.]

Chicago Exchanges Step Up Talks The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange have intensified merger talks in recent weeks as a congressional proposal threatens to put them in more direct competition in the trading of stock derivatives. Market Place. [C13.]

Fox Sues Financial Commentator The Fox News Network has filed suit in New York state court to force James J. Cramer, co-founder of TheStreet.com and commentator on its Fox cable television program, to continue appearing on the program. Fox News previously criticized Mr. Cramer for plugging a stock he owned on the program. [C8.]

France Telecom in Talks in Poland France Telecom and a Polish partner, Kulczyk Holding, received exclusive rights to negotiate the acquisition of a 35 percent stake in the former Polish phone monopoly for roughly $4 billion. The deal ushers in what will presumably be the final steps in the sale of Poland's state phone company to private investors. [C4.]
